doc_id=1753 igt_id=igt1753-58 623 625 L+CN G T

doc_id=1753 igt_id=igt1753-59 687 707 L G B M M M M M M M M M M M M M M B M B T
language: French (fra)
line=687 tag=L:  (37) Personne            (n')     a       rien    dit.
line=688 tag=G:       no one              Neg      has     nothing said
line=689 tag=B:
line=690 tag=M:    8
line=691 tag=M:      The crucial difference between Rowlett's (1998), (1998b) null Neg operator and ours is that, whereas
line=692 tag=M:  we assume that the operator is part of the N-word, he does not. On his account, French N-words are pure
line=693 tag=M:  variables. His theory cannot, however, explain the lack of quantificational variability exhibited by French
line=694 tag=M:  N-words, nor can it explain their inherent negative specification or the fact that multiple Neg constructions
line=695 tag=M:  can lead to double -negation. Our approach is more in line with Haegeman & Zanuttini (1991), and
line=696 tag=M:  Haegeman (1995, 1997). However, we discuss herein intervention effects not addressed by them.
line=697 tag=M:    9
line=698 tag=M:      The Neg feature may thus be universally strong. In West Flemish, N-words move overtly (cf.
line=699 tag=M:  Haegeman & Zanuttini 1991, Haegeman 1995, 1997) while in French we have movement of a
line=700 tag=M:  phonologically null operator. We therefore have an interesting parallel with WH constructions, since if
line=701 tag=M:  Watanabe (1993) is correct, Q is universally strong.
line=702 tag=M:    10
line=703 tag=M:         This point was explicitly made in Moritz & Valois (1994).
line=704 tag=B:
line=705 tag=M:  336   Eric Mathieu
line=706 tag=B:
line=707 tag=T:        `No one said anything.'

line=234 tag=M:    7 These verb forms may have a restricted subcategorization, compared with the
line=235 tag=M:  positive V. For instance, the verb ne-savoir i s specialized for an interrogative
line=236 tag=M:  complement, while savoir negated with pas accepts the same subcategorizations as
line=237 tag=M:  savoir.

line=4650 tag=B:
line=4651 tag=M:  178
line=4652 tag=M:      The fact that the phonological level isn't available for the logical negation isn't surprising: the entire
line=4653 tag=M:  phonological domain is opaque to the syntactic rules (though the reverse isn't true).
line=4654 tag=M:  179
line=4655 tag=M:      Maurice Maréchal, L'affaire Frick , Spirou n° 2513, 10.06.86, plate 7.
line=4656 tag=M:  180
line=4657 tag=M:      Maurice Tillieux, Le Chinois à deux roues, Dupuis, 1967, front cover.
line=4658 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                             - 71 -
line=4659 tag=B:
line=4660 tag=M:                                                                       A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
line=4661 tag=B:
line=4662 tag=T:         `It's not the road which is under the water, it's THE TRUCK THAT IS NO LONGER ON THE ROAD !'

line=5642 tag=L:  (204) Avec une partie, une petite partie, une grande partie, l'accord du verbe se fait aujourd'hui soit avec le
line=5643 tag=L:        collectif, soit avec son complément, et dépend de l'intention de celui qui parle ou qui écrit: Une petite
line=5644 tag=L+AC:        partie des dettes fut payée avec la part d'héritage. Une partie des domestiques avaient quitté l'hôtel (M.
line=5645 tag=C+AC:        Maindron, Dariolette, 286; cité par Grevisse).
line=5646 tag=T:        `With a part, a little part, a great part, verbal agreement is done nowadays either with the collective
line=5647 tag=T:        noun, or with its complement, depending on the intention of who speaks or writes: A little part of the
line=5648 tag=T+AC:        debts was paid with the inheritance part. A part of the servants had-PL left the hotel (M. Maindron,

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-861 6692 6704 M+CN L M M M M M M M M M G T
language: French (fra)
line=6692 tag=M+CN:  (239) (I) `NEGATIVE' IPS:
line=6693 tag=L:        a. ü Ça (ne) mange pas de foin!
line=6694 tag=M:  240
line=6695 tag=M:      Polarity IPs are just unmodifiable, since the sentential layer concerned with polarity is frozen by the
line=6696 tag=M:  lexicalization: there are thus no FC PIs in this category. The same holds for CPs.
line=6697 tag=M:  241
line=6698 tag=M:      See the discussion in II.3.1.2.9.2 about the idiomaticity effects of French sans and Italian senza.
line=6699 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                       - 103 -
line=6700 tag=M:
line=6701 tag=M:                                                                           A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
line=6702 tag=M:
line=6703 tag=G:         It (ne) eats not of hay!
line=6704 tag=T:         `It's economical!'

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-897 6824 6828 M+CN B L G T
language: French (fra)
line=6824 tag=M+CN:  Idiomatic VPs allowing cleavage of their complement can be freely negated:
line=6825 tag=B:

line=7395 tag=M:
line=7396 tag=M:  256

line=7589 tag=M+EX:  (281) (I) * LOGICAL DN:
line=7590 tag=L:        * Il (ne) vient [pas jamais] = ü Il vient toujours.
line=7591 tag=G:        He (ne) comes [not never] = He comes always.
line=7592 tag=T:        `He [not never] comes' = `He always comes.'

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1009 7593 7596 M+EX L G T
language: French (fra)
line=7593 tag=M+EX:        (II) ü LOGICAL NC:
line=7594 tag=L:        % Il (ne) vient pas jamais = ü Il (ne) vient jamais.
line=7595 tag=G:        He (ne) comes not never = He (ne) comes never.
line=7596 tag=T:        `He doesn't ever comes.' = `He never comes.'

line=8170 tag=L:        b. ü Je (ne) vois {* pas/ plus} rien.
line=8171 tag=M:
line=8172 tag=M:  327
line=8173 tag=M:      Serge Gainsbourg, L'herbe tendre, Philips, 1968.
line=8174 tag=M:  328
line=8175 tag=M:      It is consistent with the observation of Déprez [2000:258], "N-words with a null determiner [nouns, under our
line=8176 tag=M:  analysis] are essentially predicted to require the presence of negation, and N-words with a filled determiner
line=8177 tag=M:  [determiners and quantifiers, under our analysis] to preclude it [p. 258]".
line=8178 tag=M:  329
line=8179 tag=M:       A Generic pronoun, typically on `one', is requested by {=Specific, -Generic} NPIs. See II.3.1.1.1.2 and
line=8180 tag=M:  III.4.2.2.
line=8181 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                           - 125 -
line=8182 tag=M:
line=8183 tag=M:                                                                       A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
line=8184 tag=M:
line=8185 tag=G:         I (ne) see {not/ no-longer} nothing.

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1320 9759 9771 M+CN L G B M M M M M M M B T
language: French (fra)
line=9759 tag=M+CN:        (II) COMPOUNDED COMPLEMENTIZER:
line=9760 tag=L:        a. ü A moins {que/ de}.
line=9761 tag=G:        To less {that/ of}.
line=9762 tag=B:
line=9763 tag=M:  365
line=9764 tag=M:     Besides its complementizer-like guise with fear-verbs, ne was also an affirmative particle signifying `indeed'
line=9765 tag=M:  or `I do', and an enclitic interrogative particle; the interrogative guise of ne modifies the complementizer-like
line=9766 tag=M:  one in quin, as non does.
line=9767 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                           - 150 -
line=9768 tag=M:
line=9769 tag=M:                                                                          A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
line=9770 tag=B:
line=9771 tag=T:         `Unless that.'

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1321 9772 9774 L G T
language: French (fra)
line=9772 tag=L:         b. ü A moins {que/ de} ne pas.
line=9773 tag=G:         To less {that/ of} ne not.
line=9774 tag=T:         `Unless that not.'

line=10055 tag=G:        There ne is (not) of worse enemy than oneself.
line=10056 tag=T:        `One has no worse enemy than oneself.'

line=10429 tag=M:                                                                    A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

line=10433 tag=L:         ü Pierre mange [[et pain] [et beurre] [et fromage]].
line=10434 tag=G:         Peter eats and bread and butter and cheese.

line=10445 tag=L:        * Pierre (ne) mange [[Ø pain] [Ø fromage]].
line=10446 tag=G:        Peter (ne) eats bread cheese.

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1447 10447 10449 M+CN L G
language: French (fra)
line=10447 tag=M+CN:        (II) SYNDETICAL:
line=10448 tag=L:        * Pierre (ne) mange [[Ø pain] [ni fromage]].
line=10449 tag=G:        Peter (ne) eats bread nor cheese.

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1448 10450 10453 M+CN L G T
language: French (fra)

line=10452 tag=G:        Peter (ne) eats nor bread nor butter nor cheese.
line=10453 tag=T:        `Peter eats neither bread, neither butter, nor cheese.'

line=12215 tag=T:        `Go anyplace in my absence, and I'll give you a piece of my mind!'

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1674 12216 12218 L G T
language: French (fra)
line=12216 tag=L:        b. ü (Ne) Va pas {où que ce soit/ n'importe où} en mon absence ou tu auras de mes nouvelles!
line=12217 tag=G:        (Ne) Go not {wherever/ anyplace} in my absence or you will-have of my news!
line=12218 tag=T:        `Don't go {wherever/ anyplace} in my absence, or I'll give you a piece of my mind!'

line=12802 tag=M:     The semi-modal class probably consists of lexical verbs marginally able to be generated in functional heads,
line=12803 tag=M:  besides a regular lexical use (for instance, such a functional head could be Mood Ability for oser `to dare', which is
line=12804 tag=M:  normally generated inside as a lexical verb inside VP).

doc_id=2688 igt_id=igt2688-1806 13245 13259 L M M M M M M M M M M B M B G
language: French (fra)
line=13245 tag=L:  (544) a. * Zéro chose a été faite par Pierre.
line=13246 tag=M:  435
line=13247 tag=M:      See also Haegeman [1996] about the different properties of N-words and null numerals.
line=13248 tag=M:  436
line=13249 tag=M:      Null quantity doesn't tolerate the Presuppositional feature, hence the incompatibility with the SM, which is
line=13250 tag=M:  {-Presuppositional}, and need thus another Presuppositional item like the `negative' items.
line=13251 tag=M:  437
line=13252 tag=M:      One could think that plural agreement with `zero' follows from the linguistic meaning of cardinal numbers,
line=13253 tag=M:  which is `at least n' and not `exactly n', according to De Cornulier [1985:94-97]; if it were true, `one' too would
line=13254 tag=M:  request plural agreement.
line=13255 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                             - 204 -
line=13256 tag=B:
line=13257 tag=M:                                                                  A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA

line=13345 tag=L:  (550) [Aucun] ne prend plus guère la marque du pluriel que devant un nom qui n'a pas de singulier, ou qui a au
line=13346 tag=L:        pluriel un sens particulier: Aucuns frais. Aucuns faux frais. On ne lui fit aucunes funérailles (Lar. du XXe
line=13347 tag=L:        s.). Aucunes troupes.
line=13348 tag=T:        `[No-one] did not much take anymore the plural mark but before a noun lacking a singular form, or
line=13349 tag=T:        having at the plural a particular meaning: No-M-PL charges. No-M-PL incidental charges. One didn't make
line=13350 tag=T:        him any-F-PL obsequies (Larousse of the XXth century). No-F-PL troops.'

language: French (fra)
line=14364 tag=L:  (609) Cloud a au moins zéro dent [sic]: la bizarrerie introduite par au moins dans cet énoncé pourrait suggérer
line=14365 tag=L:        que zéro, quoique construit sans ne, a comme ne... aucun une valeur intrinsèquement restrictive; mais
line=14366 tag=L:        l'information que "Cloud a zéro dent [sic]" serait forcément vide, tout nombre possible de dents se situant
line=14367 tag=L:        entre zéro et au-dessus; zéro se combine bien avec au moins dans Maintenant qu'il fait au moins zéro
line=14368 tag=L:        degré [sic], on peut sortir sans se geler, où l'information n'est pas nulle parce que le nombre de degrés
line=14369 tag=L:        peut être inférieur à zéro.
line=14370 tag=T:        `Cloud has at least zero teeth: the oddity introduced by at least in this utterance might be suggest that
line=14371 tag=T:        zero, although built without ne, has like ne... aucun an intrinsically restrictive [= `negative'] value; but
line=14372 tag=T:        the information that "Cloud has zero teeth" should inevitably be vacuous, every possible teeth number
line=14373 tag=T:        being included between zero and more; zero combines goodly with at least in Now that it's at least zero
line=14374 tag=T:        degrees centigrade, we can go out without freezing, where the information is not null because the number
line=14375 tag=T:        of degrees centigrade can be lower than zero.'

line=17353 tag=L:        a. ü Jeanne est toujours {pétée/ stone /513 shootée }.
line=17354 tag=L+AL:        b. ü Jeanne (n')est jamais {pétée/ * stone/ * shootée}.
line=17355 tag=B:
line=17356 tag=M:  513
line=17357 tag=M:     This word became widespread in France in 1979 through the hit-song Le monde est stone from the Starmania
line=17358 tag=M:  rock-opera written by Michel Berger and Luc Plamondon; it was probably already widespread in Quebec since a
line=17359 tag=M:  while.
line=17360 tag=M:  © 2002 Yves-Ferdinand Bouvier                                                                            - 268 -
line=17361 tag=B:
line=17362 tag=M:                                                                          A   FEATURAL ACCOUNT OF POLARITY PHENOMENA
line=17363 tag=B:
line=17364 tag=G:         Jane {is always/ (ne) is never} stoned.
line=17365 tag=T:         `Jane is {always/ never} stoned.'

line=18636 tag=L:        a. ü Tu viens? - {Oui/ Non} !
line=18637 tag=G:        You come? - {Yes/ No}!
line=18638 tag=T:        `Are you coming? - {Yes (I am)/ No (I am not)}!'

language: French (fra)

line=18728 tag=L+AL:        c. ü {Il/ Elle} (ne) voit pas {âme qui vive/ * qui que ce soit}.

line=18733 tag=T:        `{I/ You/ {He/ She}/ We/ You/ They} do(es)n't see anybody.'

line=19017 tag=M:        The collocational choice for a given auxiliary or modal is motivated by further features.
line=19018 tag=M:  531
line=19019 tag=M:        Back slang of tomber `to fall', with jocular respelling motivated by a pun with an homonymous:
line=19020 tag=M:        (xcviii) Tomber  bertom  béton.
line=19021 tag=M:                 To-fall  fall-to  concrete.

doc_id=2958 igt_id=igt2958-78 1380 1404 L+SY G M M B M B M B M B M M M B M M M B M B B M B T
language: French (fra)
line=1380 tag=L+SY:              b.    Kesteri , tu sais qu'ili aime bien les poissons.
line=1381 tag=G:                    Kester you know that-he loves well the fish
line=1382 tag=M:    20
line=1383 tag=M:         Subordinate update satisfies the condition on identified by Prince (1981) and Ward and Prince (1991) which states
line=1384 tag=B:
line=1385 tag=M:  that topics must be in a partially ordered set relation to a referent in the context (i.e. a referent will be a possible topic
line=1386 tag=B:
line=1387 tag=M:  if it enters in a relation such as is taller than, is part of, is a subtype of, etc. with a referent in previous discourse).
line=1388 tag=B:
line=1389 tag=M:  However, subordinate update cannot be equated with the poset (partially ordered set) requirement (see Erteschik-Shir,
line=1390 tag=B:
line=1391 tag=M:  1997 for details).
line=1392 tag=M:    21
line=1393 tag=M:         An anonymous reviewer points out that dislocated elements are obligatory when contrastive. I do not dispute this,
line=1394 tag=B:
line=1395 tag=M:  but this is requirement is not syntactic in nature: it is due to Information Structure considerations.
line=1396 tag=M:    22
line=1397 tag=M:         In XXX I demonstrate that, even if one analyses French subject clitics as agreement markers without argument
line=1398 tag=B:
line=1399 tag=M:  status, the XP coindexed with a subject clitic is always dislocated in Spoken French.
line=1400 tag=B:
line=1401 tag=B:
line=1402 tag=M:                                                                                                  21
line=1403 tag=B:
line=1404 tag=T:                   `You know that Kester loves the fish.'

line=3430 tag=L+CR:                                                  `     ^
line=3431 tag=B:
line=3432 tag=M:    48
line=3433 tag=M:         Thetic sentences are encoded with postverbal subjects in written French but not in spoken French. In spoken
line=3434 tag=B:
line=3435 tag=M:  French, the canonical subject position can only host subjects if they are in focus (whether in narrow focus or in a thetic
line=3436 tag=B:
line=3437 tag=M:  structure). In written French, subjects in this position can receive a topic interpretation.
line=3438 tag=B:
line=3439 tag=B:
line=3440 tag=M:                                                                                                 52

doc_id=2966 igt_id=igt2966-4 493 503 L L L L L B T T T T T
language: Standard French (fra)
line=493 tag=L:           Bien que le ne soit le plus souvent employé en association avec d'autres
line=494 tag=L:           marqueurs de styles soignés, dans les expressions figées ou dans un
line=495 tag=L:           contexte métalinguistique, [Sankoff et Vincent montrent] que cette
line=496 tag=L:           particule joue toujours son rôle comme morphème de négation, même si
line=497 tag=L:           l'emploi productif du ne est très rare et redondant.
line=498 tag=B:
line=499 tag=T:               `Although the ne is most often used in association with other signs
line=500 tag=T:               of careful styles, in fixed expressions, or in a metalinguistical
line=501 tag=T:               context, [Sankoff and Vincent] show that this particle still plays its
line=502 tag=T:               role as a morpheme of negation, even if the productive use of ne is
line=503 tag=T:               very rare and redundant.'

line=1086 tag=M:                                       [ _ n __ ]
line=1087 tag=M:                                   V + /n/ +       V
line=1088 tag=M:                               [-nasal]         [+nasal]
